awd_titl_txt: Analysis of Cycles of Retributive Violence
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: Analysis of Cycles of Retributive Violence

Abstract: 
Punishing those who break the law and providing justice to victims is a fundamental duty of states. When citizens doubt the legitimacy of the state's punishments, the ability to govern breaks down, which can lead to public support for vigilante justice and further erosion of support for the rule of law. This project will analyze the factors related to support for vigilante violence. This project will study the role that information and misconceptions of state justice institutions as well as the role of emotion influence citizen support for extrajudicial punishments.

Engaging in theories from criminal justice, psychology, and political science, this study will develop, test, and implement various interventions thought to shape citizen support for extrajudicial punishments as opposed to the rule of law in Mexico. Employing a field experimental design, these interventions are designed to test different underlying reasons that citizens might support vigilante violence. A goal of this project is to identify policy interventions that reduce support for vigilantism and increase support for due process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
How do people respond to heightened insecurity and criminal violence? What factors influence support for harsh and punitive responses to crime? Are there policy interventions that can reduce support for punitive responses and increase support for the rule of law? These are important questions to both scholars and policymakers alike. To answer them, we conducted a series of research studies in Michoacan, a state in Mexico that has been plagued by high levels of criminal violence, impunity, and support for vigilante justice. 

We first conducted 66 in-depth interviews about community reactions to crime in six communities in Michoacan with varied exposure to violence and vigilante action. We asked people to talk about crimes they personally experienced, as well as several hypothetical crime scenarios. We then asked them how and why they wanted authorities or local community members to respond. We coded the transcripts from these interviews and to identify which types of moral reasoning were associated with increased support for harsh responses to crime. We expected that moralistic deontological reasoning and dehumanization would be associated with support for more punitive crime responses, while consequentialist reasoning (considering costs and benefits of different actions) and empathy would be associated with preferences for less punitive responses to crimes. 

We find results consistent with our expectations for reasoning that dehumanizes accused criminals, but find unexpected results with respect to deontological and consequentialist reasoning. We find that reasoning that involves weighing the costs and benefits of an action?consequentialist reasoning? is significantly associated with support for harsh, extrajudicial punishments. Deontological reasoning about the right or just action, while extremely common, is used more equally across arguments for and against punitive violence. Our results provide micro-foundations for theories that assume that consequentialist decision-making leads to support for punitive violence in high-violence, high-impunity settings, and show how psychological processes like dehumanization can feed into those processes.

Second, we designed and fielded an experiment to test whether different types of deliberation can reduce support for harsh, extrajudicial responses to crime. We tested two versions of a citizen deliberation process against a pure control group: 1) a standard ?cognitive? deliberation in which participants were given briefing materials and asked to weigh evidence and arguments thoughtfully, and 2) a deliberation enhanced with a group-based emotion regulation training. The cognitive deliberation (CD) training was designed to reduce support for harsh, extrajudicial punishments to the extent that information gaps (for example, about other citizens? preferences) or cognitive biases were driving support for harsh, extrajudicial punishments. The emotion regulation (ER) + deliberation treatment was designed to reduce support for harsh, extrajudicial punishments to the extent that unwanted emotional reactions to crime events drive support for harsh, extrajudicial punishments.

We then compared the preferences and beliefs of people who had been randomly selected to participate in one of the two types of deliberation sessions to those of people who were assigned to the control group and did not participate in any deliberation. In general, we found that neither treatment had a consistent impact on support for harsh, extrajudicial punishment ? and even increased support for harsh punishments in the short term on one indicator. There are several possible explanations for the results. First, both of our treatments were designed to reduce support for harsh, extrajudicial crime responses under specific conditions. The CD treatment was designed to reduce support if citizens had incorrect beliefs about others? preferences, or were subject to cognitive biases. The ER treatment was designed to reduce support if emotional reactions to crime events that participants preferred to control were driving it. One explanation for our null results is that those mechanisms are not operating in this context. Our participants may have had accurate beliefs about support for harsh punishment in their community, and did not see their emotional reactions to crime events as harmful to their judgment and behavior. 

These results suggest that while citizen deliberations may be a helpful way to collect information on citizen preferences about public safety, at least in this context and format they do not reduce support for harsh, extrajudicial punishments. This evidence runs counter to some of the more positive evidence on deliberation in polarized environments that has emerged in recent years, as well as evidence that even light-touch emotion regulation trainings can be effective in reducing anger and support for hardline policies. Policymakers instead should rely on more explicit attempts to persuade citizens, such as informing them of the risks of extrajudicial violence, or to begin with structural reforms that increase the effectiveness or legitimacy of state security institutions.
